#Text=Round the world flights
#Text=Rather than buying separate flights from one destination to another , a flexible and sometimes cheaper way of international travel is via Round the world ( RTW ) tickets .
#Text=A round the world ticket is a plane ticket allowing you to fly around the world , usually over a period of up to a year and with between 3 and 20 stops at different airports .
#Text=Computerized e-tickets seem to have reduced this to a maximum of 16 segments .

#Text=Round the world tickets usually cost far less than the sum of the one-way tickets between each set of individual stops . ( One-way tickets generally cost more than round-trip tickets on full service carriers and may be looked at with suspicion by security or border agents . )

#Text=These tickets are usually slightly more expensive than a return ticket between destinations on opposite sides of the world ( London and Sydney for example ) , but if you were planning two or more stops then you may find that a round the world ticket is the cheapest option , and allows you at least a side trip .
#Text=Many travelers plan entire holidays using a round the world itinerary .
#Text=As a much more time-consuming alternative , see also Round the world overland .
#Text=Ticket types
#Text=There are a number of ways to fly round the world .
#Text=A " real " round the world ticket is issued as a single ticket , and comes with a host of conditions attached .
#Text=Airline alliance round the world deals

#Text=Because no individual airlines offer truly global service , round the world tickets are often associated with an airline alliance and allow you to travel with any airline that is part of the alliance .
#Text=The specialist travel agents mentioned below can book these flights and provide alternative deals .
#Text=The major alliance RTW offerings available worldwide are :
#Text=Star Alliance Round the World Fare
#Text=With 28 airlines , covering over 193 countries and 1,317 destinations ( Nov 2018 ) , this is the champion for sheer number of destinations and easy routing .
#Text=The pass is available in 29,000- , 34,000- and 39,000-mile versions — in either Economy , Business or First Class — each with up to 15 stopovers .
#Text=There is also a special " Starlite " Economy-only fare for 26,000 miles , but this is limited to a maximum of 5 stopovers .
#Text=As in most of these fares , Star 's rules require passengers start and end in the same country , but not necessarily in the same city .
#Text=Some backtracking is allowed , though not over oceans .
#Text=Backtracking , surface sectors , and transits/connections all count against the mileage total .
#Text=As for where in the world you can go ?
#Text=Almost anywhere : in addition to the usual suspects , Star has a near-monopoly stranglehold on some regions including Micronesia and the South Pacific .
#Text=A black spot includes domestic flights within Australia , although there are plenty of international flights to the major cities .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :
#Text=The entire world , except ...
#Text=Weak areas :
#Text=Russia , Australia .
#Text=The 15-member Oneworld alliance offers two types of RTWs :
#Text=The unique OneWorld Explorer is based on the number of continents visited ( from three to six ) and has no maximum mileage limit .
#Text=Up to 16 segments , as opposed to stopovers , can be included — in any class of service .
#Text=However , because of that flight ( or " segment " ) ceiling , this fare can be more limiting than it first seems .
#Text=( Also , only two stopovers are permitted in the continent of origin . )
#Text=On the other hand , routings that require major backtracking ( i. e. , from Europe to Africa ) are more easily accommodated here , than they are in mile-centric fares .
#Text=Travelers are free to change the dates on their ticket at no extra charge .
#Text=Global Explorer
#Text=is Oneworld 's more conventional , mileage-based RTW ( 26,000- , 29,000- or 39,000-mile tickets in Economy class only ; 34,000 in Economy , Business or First class ) .

#Text=While the OneWorld Explorer is limited to the full members of Oneworld , several non-Oneworld alliance airlines ( including Aer Lingus , Fiji Airways , Alaska Airlines and its affiliate Horizon Air , Gulf Air and S7 Airlines .
#Text=Qantas code share flights operated by Air Tahiti Nui , Jetstar , South African Airways and Vietnam Airlines can also be used . ) can be used with the Global Explorer .
#Text=For this reason , travel to certain regions , e.g. many South Pacific islands , is easier with Global Explorer than with Oneworld Explorer .
#Text=Surface segment rules are particularly rigid and constraining on the Global Explorer , and the 16-segment restriction applies .
#Text=As with the Star Alliance mileage-based RTWs , all miles are counted , including surface segments .
#Text=Each surface segment also consumes one of the 16 permitted ticket segments .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :

#Text=North America , South America ( including the Galapagos and Easter Island ) , the Caribbean , Easter Island , Europe , Middle East , Eastern Asia , parts of the South Pacific ( Global Explorer ) , Australia , India and Russia .
#Text=Weak areas :
#Text=Intra-Africa , India , the South Pacific ( OneWorld Explorer ) .
#Text=Skyteam Round the World
#Text=.
#Text=Long a distant third , Skyteam has gone through a massive growth since 2010 and now bands together almost 20 airlines .
#Text=Its coverage of China is unparalleled , with four Chinese airlines as members , and Aeroflot ensures that Russia and Central Asia are well-covered .
#Text=Vietnam Airlines now covers South-East Asia and the Middle East , long a weak spot , now has both Saudia and Lebanon 's Middle East Airlines .
#Text=Mileage and rules are similar to Star Alliance 's RTW .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :
#Text=North America , South America , Europe , central Africa , Russia , China , Central and Eastern Asia .
#Text=Weak areas :
#Text=India , Australia , Micronesia and the South Pacific
#Text=The Great Escapade

#Text=, 29,000 miles and unlimited stops throughout the Virgin Atlantic , Air New Zealand and Singapore Airlines and SilkAir network — great coverage in South-East Asia and the Pacific , but spotty elsewhere .
#Text=Backtracking allowed .
#Text=The maximum number of stops within mileage is about 10 , e.g. London - Delhi - Bangkok - Bali - Australia Stop - New Zealand Stop - Fiji or Rarotonga - Los Angeles - London .
#Text=Prices are good value and start from £1025 including tax .

#Text=For some reason however , this ticket requires that travel must be commenced in either London UK or Manchester UK which effectively prevents North American purchasers from using a westward routing .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :
#Text=South Pacific , South-East Asia
#Text=Four Corners
#Text=.
#Text=Singapore Airlines , Lufthansa , Air New Zealand , Virgin Atlantic .
#Text=Similar to Great Escapade , but with better coverage in Europe and worse coverage in South-East Asia .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :
#Text=South Pacific , Europe
#Text=Discovery tickets
#Text=.
#Text=Qantas , Cathay Pacific , Fiji Airways , British Airways , and most Qantas codeshares .
#Text=This is probably the 2nd biggest selling RTW out of the UK , allowing 29,000 miles and 6 stops .
#Text=However an extra 1,500 miles can be bought for £100 , or 3,000 miles for £200 .
#Text=This choice is a lot cheaper than the Global Explorer and the One World , with similar routings , including Africa and South America , and from £765 plus tax .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :
#Text=Australia , Asia .
#Text=World Walkabout Plus tickets
#Text=.
#Text=Qantas , Cathay Pacific , Fiji Airways , British Airways , and most Qantas codeshares .

#Text=This is the biggest selling RTW out of the UK , allowing 29,000 miles and 7 stops - 4 can be in Australia including the point of turnaround - within a wide variety of itineraries using the joint Qantas and British Airways route networks .

#Text=Basically you 're allowed 7 stops ( including up to 3 in Australia and 3 in New Zealand ) and you must travel out and back via Australasia sticking roughly to the routings of the airlines involved .
#Text=Regions with good coverage :
#Text=Australia , Asia , United Kingdom .
#Text=Discontinued tickets include Big Planet Tour and World Journey ( Flying Dutchman ) .
